column1: Coquitlam ( koh-KWIT-ləm) is a city in the Lower Mainland of British Columbia
column2: Canada. Mainly suburban
column3: Coquitlam is the sixth-largest city in the province
column4: with a population of 139
column6: and one of the 21 municipalities comprising Metro Vancouver. The mayor is Richard Stewart.

column1: The Coast Salish people were the first to live in this area
column2: and archaeology confirms continuous occupation of the territory for at least 9
column3: 000 years. The name Kwikwetlem is said to be derived from a Coast Salish term meaning "red fish up the river".Explorer Simon Fraser came through the region in 1808
column4: and in the 1860s Europeans gradually started settling the area. Coquitlam began as a "place-in-between" with the construction of North Road in the mid-19th century to provide Royal Engineers in New Westminster access to the year-round port facilities in Port Moody.The young municipality got its first boost in 1889 when Frank Ross and James McLaren opened what would become Fraser Mills
column7: then state-of-the-art lumber mill on the north bank of the Fraser River. The District of Coquitlam was incorporated in 1891. By 1908
column8: a mill town of 20 houses
column9: a store
column10: post office
column14: pool hall and a Sikh temple had grown around the mill. A mill manager's residence was built that would later become Place des Arts.Over the next two years
column15: several contingents of French Canadian mill workers arrived from Quebec
column16: and Maillardville was born. Named for Father Edmond Maillard
column18: it became the largest Francophone centre west of Manitoba. Maillardville's past is recognized today in street names
column19: the Francophone education system and French immersion programs
column21: and celebrations such as Festival du Bois.Following World War II
column22: Coquitlam and the rest of the Lower Mainland experienced substantial population growth that continues today. The opening of Lougheed Highway in 1953 made the city more accessible and set the stage for residential growth. In 1971
column23: Coquitlam and Fraser Mills were amalgamated
column24: which gave the city a larger industrial base. The mill closed in 2001
column25: and is now rezoned into a residential area.

column1: Coquitlam is situated some 10 to 15 km (6.2 to 9.3 mi) east of Vancouver
column2: where the Coquitlam River connects with the Fraser River and extends northeast along the Pitt River toward the Coquitlam and Pitt lakes. Coquitlam borders Burnaby and Port Moody to the west
column3: New Westminster to the southwest
column4: and Port Coquitlam to the southeast. Burke Mountain
column5: Eagle Ridge
column8: 194 ft) tall Coquitlam Mountain form the northern boundary of the city. Coquitlam's area
column9: 152.5 square kilometres (58.9 sq mi)
column10: is about six times larger than either Port Moody or Port Coquitlam.Like Vancouver
column11: Coquitlam is in the Pacific Time Zone (winter UTC−8

column1: Coquitlam's geographic shape can be thought of as a tilted hourglass
column2: with two larger parcels of land with a smaller central section connecting them.

column1: Southwest Coquitlam comprises the original core of the city
column2: with Maillardville and Fraser River industrial sector giving way to the large residential areas of Austin Heights
column3: colloquially referred to as "The Bump" due to its high and flat plateau topography. These older residences
column4: with larger property dimensions
column5: are increasingly being torn down and replaced with newer and larger homes. The Poirier Street area was the city's original recreational centre with the Coquitlam Sports Centre
column8: while City Hall was previously located further south in Maillardville.The Austin Heights area contains Como Lake
column9: a renowned urban fishing and recreation area
column10: and headwaters for the Como watershed. The watershed represents one of the last urban watersheds in the Tri-Cities that supports wild stocks of coho salmon as well as other species at risk such as coastal cutthroat trout (both sea-run and resident) and bird species such as the great blue heron and green heron. It also contains Mundy Park
column11: one of the largest urban parks in the Metro Vancouver area.

column2: Coquitlam has an oceanic climate (Köppen climate type Cfb)
column3: enjoying mild temperatures and sufficient precipitation; warm/dry summers and wet/cool winters. However
column4: unlike other cities in the area
column5: precipitation is especially heavy in Coquitlam due to its proximity to the mountain slopes. With westward air moving off the Pacific Ocean
column6: the air is forced to flow up the Coast Mountains causing it to cool and condense and fall as precipitation
column7: this process is known as orographic precipitation. The orographic effect is mainly responsible for the massive 1
column8: 969 mm (77.5 in) annual average precipitation that Coquitlam receives each year
column9: with most falling as rainfall in the fall and winter months
column10: with 316 mm (12.4 in) in November; the summer is usually sunny with minimal precipitation with 60.7 mm (2.39 in) in July. Although the mild temperatures allow for mostly rain to fall during the winter months
column11: occasionally snow will fall. With a slightly higher elevation compared to the rest of Metro Vancouver
column12: Coquitlam receives an average of 64.4 cm (25.4 in) of snow each year
column13: with it rarely staying on the ground for a few days
column14: adding to a very intermittent snow cover during the winter season.

column1: Coquitlam is also located in one of the warmest regions in Canada where average mean annual temperature is 10.2 °C (50.4 °F). Temperatures are warm during the summer months with an average high of 22.7 °C (72.9 °F)
column2: and an average low of 13.4 °C (56.1 °F) in August. During the winter months
column3: the average high is 5.6 °C (42.1 °F)
column4: and the average low is 0.9 °C (33.6 °F) in December. This relatively mild climate
column5: by Canadian standards
column6: is caused by the warm Alaska Current offshore and the many mountain ranges preventing the cold arctic air from the rest of Canada from reaching the southwest corner of British Columbia.

column1: The city has four SkyTrain stations on the Millennium Line that are a part of the 10.9 km (6.8 mi) long Evergreen Extension. With a project cost of $1.4 billion
